Butt c Xiaoming Zhang a b ⁎ Chuanbo Li a b ⁎ a School of Science, Minzu University of China, Beijing 100081, China School of Science Minzu University of China Beijing 100081 China aSchool of Science, Minzu University of China, Beijing 100081, China b Optoelectronics Research Center, Minzu University of China, Beijing 100081, China Optoelectronics Research Center Minzu University of China Beijing 100081 China bOptoelectronics Research Center, Minzu University of China, Beijing 100081, China c Department of Physics, Division of Science and Technology, University of Education Lahore, 54770 Lahore, Pakistan Department of Physics Division of Science and Technology University of Education Lahore Lahore 54770 Pakistan cDepartment of Physics, Division of Science and Technology, University of Education Lahore, 54770 Lahore, Pakistan ⁎ Corresponding authors. Recently, the assembly of novel two-dimensional materials via van der Waals (vdW) interactions to form heterostructures is considered an effective strategy for producing materials with enhanced photocatalytic activities. This study systematically explored the optoelectronic and photocatalytic properties and carrier mobilities of novel ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) vdW heterostructures using density functional theory. The formation energies, elastic constants, phonon dispersions, and results of ab-initio molecular dynamic simulations indicate structural, mechanical, dynamic, and thermal stability. The electronic band structure and optical properties are calculated using hybrid functional HSE06 for accurate calculations. The results of calculations using the bandgap center technique based on density functional theory show that ZrSSe/SnSe, ZrSSe/SnS2, and ZrSSe/SnSe2 heterostructures possess suitable band edges for photocatalytic overall water splitting. The optical absorption spectrum covers a broad range from 104 in the visible region and increases to 105 in the UV region. Furthermore, the ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) heterostructures have high carrier mobilities of the order of 105. High mobilities help carriers to move quickly and reduce the recombination rate of holes and electrons. The findings indicate that ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) heterostructures are potentially efficient visible-light photocatalysts for overall water splitting. Introduction Global industrialization and population growth are resulting in a growing energy demand. Fossil fuels have long been a primary energy source to meet daily energy requirements. Fossil fuels are not only a non-renewable energy resource, but also main contributors to greenhouse gas emissions and pollution [1]. Alternatives to fossil fuels include environmentally friendly and renewable energy resources such as solar, wind, nuclear, and hydroelectric energy [2]. In addition, hydrogen is an alternative clean and renewable energy resource with the potential to overcome the above-mentioned issues [3,4]. Hydrogen can be generated by various techniques, among which water splitting using sunlight is one of the most attractive methods because it is a carbon-free process that mainly uses Earth-abundant materials [5–7]. Vertically aligned van der Waals heterostructures (vdWHs) comprising the same and different 2D structures have received research interest because of the potential advantages of their integral layers [8,9]. Recently, chemical vapor deposition (CVD) and epitaxial-growth techniques have been used to fabricate various vertical vdWHs, such as MoS2/h-BN [10], SnS/SnS2 [11] and SnSe/MoSe2 [12]. 2D vdWHs are currently considered feasible for developing innovative optical and electronic devices with distinctive properties not observed intrinsic to the integral layers. Specifically, novel 2D vdWHs with staggered bandgap (type-II) configurations have exhibited outstanding performance in photovoltaic devices [13–15] and photocatalysis [16–19] owing to their fascinating optical and electronic properties. After the successful synthesis of graphene and the demonstration of its unique properties, two-dimensional (2D) materials have attracted the interest of researchers for many applications. Specifically, 2D materials have been studied for photocatalytic water splitting. 2D materials exhibit higher carrier mobilities than 3D materials, which helps reduce the charge carrier recombination rates [20]. Among the many 2D materials, tin chalcogenides are appealing semiconductor materials and abundantly utilized in photocatalytic water splitting [21], lithium-ion batteries [22], gas sensors [23], and optoelectronic devices [11]. Tin chalcogenides (S- and Se-based) usually have wide bandgaps, are inexpensive, nontoxic, stable in acidic and neutral environments, and thermally stable in air [24]. Guo et al. showed that Janus ZrSSe, an indirect semiconductor, is mechanically and dynamically stable and exhibits high photocatalytic activities [25]. Furthermore, after the successful fabrication of Janus MoSSe layers by the selenization of MoS2, it is easy to synthesize Janus ZrSSe monolayers by the selenization of ZrS2 monolayers [26]. Therefore, in this study, we theoretically designed vdWHs of ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) and studied their stabilities (structural, mechanical, dynamic, and thermal) along with their optoelectronic and photocatalytic properties. The calculations also indicated that these heterostructures have high charge carrier (electron and hole) mobilities, making them viable candidates as photocatalysts for overall water splitting under visible light. Computational method Density functional theory (DFT)-based first-principles calculations were performed in this study using CASTEP code [27,28], which applies a plane-wave pseudopotential approach. A vacuum region of 20 Å was applied to omit any fictitious interactions between the 2D layers of ZrSSe and SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2). Within the framework of the generalized gradient approximation (GGA), the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) approach was used to treat electron exchange correlation [29,30]. The Broyden–Fletcher–Goldfarb–Shanno (BFGS) algorithm was employed to relax the structures [31,32]. The dispersion-corrected method (DFT-D3) was employed to treat the van der Waals interactions because it is suitable for representing vdWHs [33]. A cutoff energy of 500 eV was used for the expansion of the wave functions. The Brillouin zone was integrated using the Monkhorst–Pack [34] scheme with 6 × 6 × 1 k-points. However, the density of states (DOS) and optical properties (absorption spectra) were evaluated at 20 × 20 × 1 k-points. An accurate estimation of the electronic band structure was performed by applying the Heyd–Scuseria–Ernzerhof (HSE06) exchange–correlation functional [35]. Furthermore, to assess the thermal stability of ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) heterostructures, we performed ab-initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations with a 3 × 3 × 1 supercell, self-consistent field (SCF) value of 1.0 × 10−8 eV atom−1, max displacement of 5 × 10−4 Å, key force convergence value of 0.01 eVÅ−1, and pressure of 0.02 GPa. The Elastool package was used to evaluate elastic constants [36]. Results and discussion Structural optimization Side views of the crystal structures of ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) heterostructures are presented in Fig. 1 . The blue, pink, yellow, and green circles correspond to the Sn, Zr, S, and Se atoms, respectively. SnS2, SnSe2, and ZrSSe are layered structures that are packed hexagonally, where Sn is packed between two S or Se atoms and Zr is packed between S and Se atoms, respectively. The electronegativity difference between S and Se atoms generates the inequivalent bond lengths of Zr–S and Zr–Se. The optimized lattice parameters are 3.74, 3.78, 3.72, and 3.79 Å, for ZrSSe/SnS, ZrSSe/SnSe, ZrSSe/SnS2, and ZrSSe/SnSe2 heterostructures, respectively. The bond lengths are Zr–Se = 2.68 Å, Zr–S = 2.56 Å, Sn–S = 2.61 Å, and Sn–Se = 2.71 Å. Stability The elastic constants act like a bridge between the dynamic properties, mechanical properties, and the description of forces that occur inside the material, such as stability and stiffness [37]. The mechanical stability of the ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) vdWHs was evaluated and elastic isotropy was observed owing to the hexagonal symmetry, where C11, C12, and C66 are independent elastic constants and C11 = C22. The criteria for mechanical stability is C11C22 − C 12 2 > 0, and C11, C22, C66 > 0 [38]. Based on these criteria, all four of the analyzed vdWHs are mechanically stable. Other mechanical properties like Young's modulus, Poisson's ratio etc. are given in supplementary information file (Fig. S1). The formation energy (E f) values of all ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) vdWHs were calculated to evaluate the ease of synthesizing the structures using E f = (E SnX/ZrSSe −E SnX −E ZrSSe), where E SnX/ZrSSe, E SnX, and EZrSSe are the energies of the ZrSSe/SnX vdWHs, and ZrSSe and SnX single layers, respectively. The calculated results are illustrated in Fig. 2 (a). Negative E f values indicate exothermic reactions to form the vdWHs, implying that can be readily fabricated from ZrSSe and SnX single layers. Among these heterostructures, ZrSSe/SnS2 is the most stable and the E f values follow the order ZrSSe/SnS2 > ZrSSe/SnS > ZrSSe/SnSe2 > ZrSSe/SnSe. It is worth noting that the E f values of the four vdWHs are very minimum, indicating that they can form concurrently. The dynamic stabilities of ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) vdWHs were assessed by calculating the phonon dispersions. The computed phonon dispersion of the ZrSSe/SnS heterostructure is depicted in Fig. 2(b), whereas phonon dispersions of ZrSSe/SnSe, ZrSSe/SnS2, and ZrSSe/SnSe2 are shown in the Supplementary Information (Fig. S2(a-c)). There are no soft modes throughout the entire Brillouin zone, which illustrates the dynamic stability of these vdWHs. There are three branches of acoustic phonons and fifteen branches of optical phonons. The three lowermost acoustic branches were identified as the in-plane longitudinal acoustic (LA), flexural acoustic (FA) out-of-plane, and transverse acoustic (TA) branches. These branches have quadratic frequencies and around Γ point frequencies leads to be zero, which is typical in 2D materials. Around 6.2 THz, there is very little phonon dispersion (homopolar mode), which is attributed to the layered structure [39]. The phonon dispersion spectra indicate the possibility of synthesizing the ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) vdWHs. Furthermore, the thermal stability of these vdWHs was evaluated by performing AIMD simulations using the standard NVT ensemble at 300 K after relaxing the heterostructures for 10 ps. Fig. 2(c) shows the simulation step, temperature fluctuations, and change in the total energy of the SnS/ZrSSe heterostructure over time. The corresponding results for ZrSSe/SnSe, ZrSSe/SnS2, and ZrSSe/SnSe2 heterostructures are given in Fig. S3(a-c). The energy variation during the AIMD simulation is very small and the heterostructures vibrate very little at 300 K, indicating good thermal stability. Electronic properties The band structure provides significant information about the properties of ZrSSe and SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) monolayers and vdWHs. The Fermi energy level (E f) was set to zero for post-processing calculations, since the physical properties of solid materials are generally affected by the electronic structure near E f [40]. The band structures of ZrSSe and SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) monolayers and vdWHs were investigated using a hybrid potential (HSE06) because the GGA usually underestimates the band gap [41]. The calculated electronic band structures of the proposed heterostructures are depicted in Fig. 3 (a-d) whereas the band structures of the monolayers are provided in supplementary information (Fig. S4(a-e)). The conduction-band minimum (CBM) lies at the M-point for all heterostructures, while the valence-band maximum (VBM) for ZrSSe/SnS2 and ZrSSe/SnSe2 lies at the Γ-point while for ZrSSe/SnS and ZrSSe/SnSe, it lies between the Γ and K points. The band gaps of ZrSSe/SnS, ZrSSe/SnSe, ZrSSe/SnS2, and ZrSSe/SnSe2 heterostructures are all indirect, and the values determined using HSE06 are 1.295, 1.207, 1.372, and 1.587 eV, respectively (Table 1 ). The band gaps measured using HSE06 are higher than those determined using GGA, because GGA poorly describes the strong Coulombic interactions and correlation breaking in the exchange–correlation potential. Density of states Furthermore, the composition and structure of the energy bands were explored by investigating the projected DOS (Fig. 4 (a-d)). The dotted black line corresponds to E f, with the conduction and valance bands on the right and left sides of the E f, respectively. The orange and blue lines denote the DOS of ZrSSe and SnX, respectively, in ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) heterostructures. In the case of ZrSSe/SnS2 and ZrSSe/SnSe2, the major contribution in the conduction band near E f is from ZrSSe, but the orbitals of SnS2/SnSe2 are also hybridized with those of ZrSSe. On the other hand, in the valence band near E f, the major contribution is from ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) with orbitals of ZrSSe hybridized with those of SnX. In the energy range of −2 to −5 eV, the major contribution is from the orbitals of ZrSSe, while the orbitals of SnX are also hybridized with those of ZrSSe, but their contribution is small. For ZrSSe/SnS, ZrSSe/SnSe, and ZrSSe/SnSe2 vdWHs, it is clear that the VBM and CBM are confined in SnX (X = S, Se, Se2) and ZrSSe, respectively, indicating type-II band alignment. However, for ZrSSe/SnS2, the VBM and CBM are confined in ZrSSe, indicating type-I band alignment. Band alignment For several decades, photocatalytic water splitting to generate hydrogen and oxygen has been investigated as an attractive option for addressing energy shortage by producing green and environmentally friendly energy [42–44]. The band-edge positions can be predicted using two approaches. First approach is a semiempirical method proposed by Butler and Ginely [45] which is based on Eqs. (1) & 2 [46,47]. (1) E CBM = X − E e − 1 2 E g H S E 06 (2) E VBM = E CBM + E g H S E 06 In the above equations, X is the electronegativity and E e is the free-electron energy on the hydrogen scale (4.5 eV). As displayed in Fig. 5 , ΔE C is the energy difference between the oxidation potential of water and the valence band and ΔE V is the energy difference between the conduction band and reduction potential of water. ΔE C and ΔE V are called kinetic overpotentials and they have significant importance for driving redox reactions. Table 1 shows the calculated values of ΔE C and ΔE V for the studied heterostructures. The band-edge positions of ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) heterostructures calculated using the empirical formulas are favorable for overall photocatalytic water splitting. However, the band-edge positions of ZrSSe/SnS are only suitable for the oxidation reaction but not the reduction reaction. Second approach is bandgap-center based DFT scheme. It has been shown that DFT can be used to calculate the bandgap-center energy (E BGC) accurately [48], although Kohn–Sham DFT show errors while evaluating the exchange-correlation energy (XC). However, E BGC is independent of the functional used for calculating XC [49]. The PBE approach is used to lower the computational cost when calculating E BGC. Then, E g H S E 06 is used in place of E g P B E . Based on E BGC theory, the DFT scheme is implemented to compute the positions of the valence and conduction band edges using Eq. (3). (3) E C B M / V B M = E B G C ± 1 2 E g H S E The electrostatic potential, BGC energy, and band edge positions (CBM and VBM) for ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) vdWHs are depicted in Fig. 6 , along with the water-splitting redox potentials. All of the above-mentioned energy levels are presented with respect to the vacuum level (dashed black line). The redox levels of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) are indicated by dotted blue and red lines, respectively, whereas the bandgap center is depicted by a solid magenta line. Generally, the photocatalytic reaction rate depends on the differences between the CBM and HER (or OER and VBM), where reducing the energy difference increases the reaction rate [50]. In stacked heterostructures, electrons flow from SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) layers towards ZrSSe layer due to the electronegativity difference until the Fermi levels of both ZrSSe and SnX monolayers are perfectly aligned. An intrinsic electric field (E int), denoted by the black arrows in Fig. 6, is developed due to a dipole moment directed from the SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) layer towards the ZrSSe layer. Moreover, this E int allows the flow of extra electrons to ZrSSe layer and holes towards SnX layer, hindering the reintegration of photogenerated holes and electrons. The HER occurs on the ZrSSe layer and the OER occurs on the SnX layer. ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) heterostructures effectively separate electrons and holes and have large enough ΔE C and ΔE V values for redox reactions due to their suitable ΔV values (Fig. S5 and Table 1). Fig. 6 shows that ZrSSe/SnSe, ZrSSe/SnS2, and ZrSSe/SnSe2 heterostructures have suitable band-edge positions for overall photocatalytic water splitting whereas ZrSSe/SnS is only suitable for water oxidation. The results obtained by the empirical method and DFT are consistent. Furthermore, the results illustrate that ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) heterostructures are favorable photocatalysts for overall water splitting over a broad spectral range. Absorption It is important to evaluate the optical properties of a system, such as the linear response and transmission behavior [51]. Various optical properties can be elucidated by calculating the complex dielectric function ε = ε r ( ω ) + i ε i ( ω ) . The Momentum matrix of unoccupied and occupied states, i ε i ( ω ) , is used to estimate the imaginary part of the dielectric function. The absorption coefficient (α) and imaginary part of the dielectric function (ε2(ω)) were determined using Eqs. (4) and 5 [52,53]. (4) ε 2 ( ω ) = 2 π 2 e Ω ε 0 ∑ k , ν , c | ψ k c | μ . r | ψ k v | δ ( E k c − E k v − E ) (5) α ( ω ) = 2 ω c [ ε 1 2 ( ω ) + ε 2 2 ( ω ) − ε 1 ( ω ) ] 1 2 Here, u is the incident polarization field, ω is the light frequency, Ψ k c and Ψ k v are the electric charges, where υ and c indicate the wave functions of the conduction and valence band, respectively. In addition to favorable band-edge positions, the light absorption efficiency of a photocatalytic material in sunlight is of great importance for determining its overall water-splitting performance [54]. An efficient photocatalyst should exhibit an absorption spectrum that covers the visible region of the solar spectrum. The absorption spectra of the ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) heterostructures are presented in Fig. 7 . These materials exhibit some IR absorption but there are no prominent peaks in this region. However, in the visible region (∼2–3.6 eV) there are considerable absorption peaks for all heterostructures. The absorption coefficient steadily increases from 104 cm−1 in the visible to 105 cm−1 in the UV region for all heterostructures. All of the studied vdWHs absorb sunlight over a broad spectral range, from visible to UV, with a high coefficient of absorption. Charge density The electrical characteristics of ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) vdWHs were studied in detail by investigating the differential of the planar-average charge density in the z-direction Δρ(z) using the following equation. (6) Δ ρ ( z ) = ρ v d W H ( z ) − ρ Z r S S e ( z ) − ρ S n X ( z ) Here, the plane-averaged charge densities of the ZrSSe/SnX vdWH, pristine ZrSSe monolayers, and SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) are depicted by ρ v d W H ( z ) , ρ Z r S S e ( z ) and ρ S n X ( z ) , respectively. Charge relocation occurs at ZrSSe/SnX heterojunctions because of areas with high hole or electron concentrations (Fig. 8 (a-d)). Charge-relocation factors, such as charge depletion (yellow isosurface) and accumulation (blue isosurface), are known to produce interfacial dipoles and electron polarization. In addition, negative values indicate depletion and positive values indicate accumulation of charge. The influence of repulsion by surface charges is exhibited by charge depletion, which promptly causes the rehybridization of the surface orbitals. Mobility The carrier mobility is an essential material parameter in the development of photocatalysts [55]. At room temperature, the mobility of 2D materials is governed by the scattering of acoustic phonons via the intra- and inter-valley deformation potential (DP). DP theory was used to compute the carrier mobilities using the following equation. (7) μ 2 D = 2 e ℏ 3 C 3 K B T | m * | 2 E d 2 Here, m* is the effective mass, e is the charge of an electron, K B is Boltzmann's constant, and T is the temperature (300 K in this study). The strain-induced band-edge shift (DP constant) and elastic modulus are represented by E d and C respectively. Here, C = [ ∂ 2 E / ∂ ε 2 ]/S, where S is the area of the system and E is the total energy under the applied uniaxial strain (ε= Δa/a0, where a0 is the initial lattice constant of the heterostructure). The calculated values of m*, C, E d, and the carrier mobilities (of electrons and holes) for ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) vdWHs are given in Table 2 . The evaluated VBM and CBM positions and relative energies of the heterostructures as a function of uniaxial strain along the armchair and zigzag directions are given in Figs. (S6, S7) and Fig. S8 respectively. Table 2 shows that the electron mobilities (armchair and zigzag direction) are greater than the hole mobilities for ZrSSe/SnS, ZrSSe/SnSe, and ZrSSe/SnSe2 heterostructures, whereas the hole mobilities are higher than the electron mobilities for ZrSSe/SnS2. The likelihood of the recombination of photogenerated carriers is minimized due to the difference in the magnitudes of the mobilities of holes and electrons, which is highly favorable for enhancing the photocatalytic activities of the heterostructures [56]. The carrier mobilities of ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) vdWHs are higher than many 2D semiconductor materials such as BN [57]; InAs [58]; MoS2 [59]; InSe/MoSe2 [60]; InSe [61]; GaP/GaSe [62]; hBNC/Janus WSSe [63]; 1T-SnS2/MoTe2 [64]; SnS, SnSe, SnS2, and SnSe2 [65]; and phosphorene [66] and comparable to some organic electronic materials [67]. The very high mobility of photogenerated electrons and holes enables the carriers to migrate quickly toward the interface of the heterostructures to contribute to the redox reactions. Higher carrier mobilities (in the range of 105 cm2 v − 1 s − 1) indicate that ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) heterostructures are favorable candidates for overall photocatalytic water splitting for hydrogen production. Conclusion In this study, we systematically calculated the optoelectronic properties, photocatalytic activities, and carrier mobilities of ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) vdWHs using DFT. The structural, mechanical, dynamic, and thermal stabilities of these materials were also assessed by calculating the formation energies, elastic constants, phonon dispersions, and molecular dynamic simulations. Accurate band structures of all heterostructures were calculated by employing the hybrid HSE06 functional because the GGA method underestimates the bandgap. The calculated bandgaps range from 1.2 eV to 1.6 eV. BGC-based DFT was used to calculate the band-edge positions for the redox reactions for water splitting (HER and OER). ZrSSe/SnSe, ZrSSe/SnS2, and ZrSSe/SnSe2 heterostructures have suitable band edges for overall photocatalytic water splitting. The absorption spectra of the heterojunctions indicate visible light harvesting with an absorption coefficient of 104, which increases to 105 in the UV region. Furthermore, the calculated carrier mobilities of the heterostructures are in the range of 105 cm2 v − 1 s − 1, which is considered sufficiently high. The differences in the magnitude of the hole and electron mobilities are highly favorable for facilitating carrier transport and reducing the recombination rate. The results of this study illustrate that the ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) vdWHs are suitable candidates as photocatalysts for overall water splitting with high carrier mobility, visible-light activity, and suitable stability. coredata.dc:description: Recently, the assembly of novel two-dimensional materials via van der Waals (vdW) interactions to form heterostructures is considered an effective strategy for producing materials with enhanced photocatalytic activities. This study systematically explored the optoelectronic and photocatalytic properties and carrier mobilities of novel ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) vdW heterostructures using density functional theory. The formation energies, elastic constants, phonon dispersions, and results of ab-initio molecular dynamic simulations indicate structural, mechanical, dynamic, and thermal stability. The electronic band structure and optical properties are calculated using hybrid functional HSE06 for accurate calculations. The results of calculations using the bandgap center technique based on density functional theory show that ZrSSe/SnSe, ZrSSe/SnS2, and ZrSSe/SnSe2 heterostructures possess suitable band edges for photocatalytic overall water splitting. The optical absorption spectrum covers a broad range from 104 in the visible region and increases to 105 in the UV region. Furthermore, the ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) heterostructures have high carrier mobilities of the order of 105. High mobilities help carriers to move quickly and reduce the recombination rate of holes and electrons. The findings indicate that ZrSSe/SnX (X = S, Se, S2, Se2) heterostructures are potentially efficient visible-light photocatalysts for overall water splitting.
coredata.dc:title: High carrier mobility ZrSSe/SnX (X=S, Se, S2, Se2) vdW heterostructures for photocatalytic overall water splitting: A first-principles study
